Text: The UK must always be assessed in relation to the rest of the world, and thus in relation to the country that we are – both in terms of geographic size and population. The knowledge society is our pride, and with continued communication to the citizens, actions are influenced most effectively. The UK is best governed by trust in its citizens – guidance and increased knowledge will work best.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: Regardless of the significant national task of reducing CO2, this should not mean that our basic cost of living should increase further. It would affect society unevenly and create inequality. A number of measures have already been introduced, for example in grocery stores, to reduce food waste through cheaper product groups that are close to their expiration dates, among other things.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: Economy is one of the biggest behavioral drivers for so-called ordinary people. A higher tax can help initiate the conversation about having to pay for the burden one places on the planet/earth/the rest of the world. One could try to find a model that is dependent on wealth, so that it’s not only the pensioner who has to pay a significant portion of their disposable income for a flight to Spain in the winter, but also so that the wealthy feel it when they fly by private jet from Copenhagen to Aarhus for a coffee meeting.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: Expensive groceries affect people who don’t have much to get by with. We want to live healthily, not become overweight, and it can lead to high cholesterol if food isn’t of good quality and you choose poor foods because of the price. Everyone needs heat, and many still use oil and gas for heating. Where I live, district heating has gradually become widespread where it’s possible.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: There are a great many initiatives we use to nudge the population to make the decisions that make the most sense. In a world that is getting warmer and warmer, which, for example, makes it more expensive to import goods, causes people to flee from natural disasters (so we are faced with integration efforts), and makes it harder for agriculture to cultivate, it makes good sense to adjust the levers we have.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: I believe it will create bureaucracy. In principle, I am against special taxes. Either things are legal, or they are illegal. And suddenly there will be a political battle over which category something ends up in. It will be a field day for lobbyists, because there are many gray areas. And it supports the idea that it will become bureaucratic for both the state and private companies. Furthermore, I do not like the behavioral regulation inherent in special taxes.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: In the uncertain times we are experiencing right now across the world, where everyone is at odds with each other, and with the continued rapid development of electric cars, which may lack power, it may become necessary to secure our heating and electricity supply with gas and oil from the North Sea. The UK is the teacher’s pet and actually lives up to many of the new energy initiatives coming in from the EU and the rest of the world. Therefore, it may become necessary to be more self-sufficient before all our productive land has been turned into fields of iron — and here I am referring to solar panel installations.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: The UK already provides relatively more aid to developing countries than other countries. I do not see a need for the UK to contribute significantly more to this purpose than other countries. the UK cannot solve the challenges alone. I would also suggest that we restructure our efforts and make a greater effort to strengthen partnerships and cooperation within green transition, education, and business collaboration. This will be help to self-help and will be better than development aid.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: We have a number of serious climate challenges that are becoming more and more uncontrollable. That’s why I think it’s extremely important to reduce CO2. Price differentiation is one of the ways that can really help influence people’s behavior. And at the same time, people feel that it’s their own choice whether they want to change their behavior or not.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: Own extraction ensures less dependence on, among others, Russia. We should not have our own extraction forever, but over time use the revenues from our own extraction to invest in the green transition. Instead of importing oil and gas, there is a lower climate footprint with our own extraction. Finally, it also helps to increase export revenues for the UK, and it also ensures, for example, Germany or other EU countries greater independence from Russia.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: The UK distributes development aid too uncritically. There is too little follow-up on whether the money actually contributes to development in the recipient countries. We should therefore strengthen the analysis phase and the follow-up on the projects that are supported, so that we have greater certainty that the aid actually benefits the objectives we wish to promote.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: We need to prioritize the welfare of Brits first. The public schools are worn down. Home care is sluggish. There are not enough educators in our daycare centers. Brits work hard, and therefore we should instead use the money for a proper welfare society. Spending the money on development aid can also undermine trust in the tax system if the money just disappears out into the world. We also cannot be sure what the money is used for, who receives it, and whether it makes a real difference.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: The UK is one of the richest countries in the world. We cannot just look after ourselves and be indifferent to how the rest of the world is doing. We are a member of the UN, we have ratified the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the Convention on the Rights of the Child. We must support development in developing countries so that they can eventually become economically sustainable. In the fight for the environment and climate, the world must stand together; we are also better off here, and therefore we must also provide help in this area.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: We must preserve the Earth for our grandchildren. This is not an easy task, and therefore we need to use public funds to make an effort for the climate while also making it cheaper for businesses and citizens to make choices that benefit the climate. In this regard, CO2 taxes are a good option. After all, we often choose the cheapest solution if there are several good options. CO2 taxes will also promote the development of alternatives. To ensure that the taxes do not make life difficult for the poorest, they should be compensated through a "green check" via the tax system, which we have already used in previous environmental initiatives.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: We are already highly taxed and have many and high duties on various goods. It is the wrong approach to make things more expensive, as it will affect the poor population, who already have enough to struggle with. Instead, more support schemes should be provided rather than trying to get people to change their behavior and install other technologies.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: The UK spends over 20 billion on development aid, including many billions to NGOs such as Oxfam and the Red Cross, which have viewpoints regarding the Gaza conflict, for example, that have nothing to do with development aid, so why support these left-wing viewpoints with taxpayers’ money? Furthermore, the UK needs to spend many additional billions annually to rebuild the military, so one could take 10 million out of the 20 billion in development aid and use them for the military. There are no facts that actually document whether development aid really helps.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: The UK’s economic and social resources are not unlimited. If more asylum seekers arrive, it will put pressure on the healthcare system, the school system, and welfare. The integration of the refugees who are already in the UK is not going particularly well: high unemployment, parallel societies, social control, crime and radicalization in certain environments, cultural strain (wildly different views on freedom of expression, gender equality, homosexuality, etc.). We should help in the local areas, but we cannot take on all the world’s problems. The system attracts migrants with economic motives rather than genuine refugees.
Issue: accept more asylum seekers fleeing war or persecution.

Text: We must prioritize our own energy sources highly in this unstable world. There are parts of our societal functions that require oil, and the gas network is established, which in my opinion legitimizes continued use of gas when we compare CO2 emissions with the establishment of new infrastructure. The increased risk of war situations is a far worse scenario for CO2 emissions than our daily consumption.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: Historically, Brits have been helped by other countries, and of course we should help where we can. We should try to help as much as possible in the local area, but we should also help some here in the UK. Can we sleep well at night if we know that other people are suffering? We can't save everyone, but we can help some.
Issue: accept more asylum seekers fleeing war or persecution.

Text: I believe it is important that we do not reduce spending on development aid. It is important that we help locally, so we do not depopulate an area that is struggling. If we depopulate an area, it becomes difficult to get the area/population back on its feet again. It is cheaper to help locally, and in this way we can help more people locally than if the population ends up as refugees instead.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: We need to reduce CO2 emissions to save the planet from further warming. The increasing warming we already have is too high and must be reduced. I have to assume that my fellow human beings, through the press, are informed about all the increasing disasters that have already occurred and which must be stopped/reduced as quickly as possible. After all, they are created by us humans; therefore, it is also up to us to change it.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: The UK is a wealthy country by global standards. If we cannot receive refugees, then who can? It is basic human decency. If the most vulnerable refugees cannot get away, we risk that the conflicts will spread to the detriment of everyone. Furthermore, we have promised the international community to receive about 500 refugees per year — we are not fulfilling that, which damages the way other countries see us, and thus our opportunities for trade, etc.
Issue: accept more asylum seekers fleeing war or persecution.

Text: As one of the world’s richest countries and one of the countries that affects the climate the most, we have an obligation to help countries with fewer resources provide their citizens with a decent life. That is the right thing to do. Another argument could be that if we do not help, then people from poorer and less developed countries will move toward the richer part of the world, which is completely understandable. Who wouldn’t want a good life with security in terms of food, work, and a roof over their head? Finally, it would also mean a less conflict-ridden world, which is also to our benefit.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: We must reduce CO2 emissions to stop climate change, which can make our planet uninhabitable and worsen life for people everywhere on Earth. Reducing CO2 can be achieved by everyone changing their lifestyle, both businesses and individuals. Experience with letting this happen voluntarily has shown that it does not happen quickly enough. Therefore, the state needs to help citizens live in a more climate-friendly way. This can be done by making it cheaper to live in a climate-friendly way and more expensive to emit CO2. Economic arguments are not always correct, but in this situation they work.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: Support should be provided in nearby areas within the same cultural sphere. It creates far too much tension in British society when many people come to the UK who do not share the same values as we have in the UK—both democratic and religious values, mutual respect, ethical and moral values, but also values regarding behavior and child-rearing.
Issue: accept more asylum seekers fleeing war or persecution.

Text: We need to use the money here at home to improve our welfare. There are constant cutbacks to our elderly care and our schools, so the money should go there. The elderly are having their home assistance limited, and schoolchildren cannot get the right opportunities for development and support in schools, especially special programs.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: The climate is running wild with floods, cloudbursts, and drought. We need to limit the consumption of the groceries and energy that emit the most CO2. It must be worthwhile to reduce greenhouse gas pollution for the benefit of the UK and the entire planet. Our children and grandchildren expect this of us. There is no Planet B.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: I do not think the government should reduce spending on development aid, as it is crucial for a peaceful world that we continue to teach developing countries about democracy. There are many young democracies in the world that need our assistance to continue the work they have started. I have personally been deployed and have seen how much of a difference relatively small amounts can make. The UK can contribute with knowledge and know-how — and at a time when democracy is under pressure worldwide, it is essential that we maintain our development aid.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: As a country, we are not skilled enough to handle more asylum seekers at the present time. We should work on ensuring that those who are already here receive an education and a job, so they can become self-sufficient and contribute to society. If we are to receive more asylum seekers, it must be ensured that they become self-sufficient so they contribute to society.
Issue: accept more asylum seekers fleeing war or persecution.

Text: We have a responsibility for others besides ourselves and our own navel. This is about global solidarity. It should promote development in the countries concerned, so that they can create progress, become economically, socially, climatically and environmentally, as well as democratically self-sustaining, and at the same time raise the income and living standards of their populations, including through internal distribution policies.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: We need to reduce CO2 emissions to stop climate change. It is us who have polluted and emitted, and it is us who must reverse the trend. We do not have time to wait for everyone to change their behavior voluntarily, and we know that the most effective tool for changing behavior is to tax what we want less of. In return, we can lower taxes, such as VAT, on the goods we want people to use instead.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: CO2 emissions are already costing all of us. It costs in the form of fear for the future, it costs economically due to an increasing need for climate protection, and it costs economically due to higher insurance expenses. The longer it takes before CO2 emissions are stopped, the higher the costs will be. There is a tradition of making the polluter pay. Therefore, taxes on climate-polluting everyday goods and energy are entirely in line with custom.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: When people flee from war and persecution, it is out of necessity and not by choice. Our society is built on a Christian fundamental attitude that one helps others in need. It is important that we distinguish between immigrants who seek their own fortune by coming to, for example, the UK, and refugees who are forced to flee due to war, persecution, or natural disasters. It is a fact that “new” Brits have helped make the UK a richer country. And throughout history, we have drawn inspiration for development through contact with people from other cultures.
Issue: accept more asylum seekers fleeing war or persecution.

Text: We all have a responsibility through our behavior. And if some people consume in a way that is destructive to the climate, it is an abuse of our shared resources. And here, taxes can be a useful tool, even though I am fundamentally opposed to the tax system, as it is often hidden taxes. And in a country like the UK, with a high tax burden, we need to be especially cautious. But intelligent taxes are welcome and should be designed according to their purpose.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: Since 1870, we have heavily relied on the fossil fuels that the Earth has taken 4.5 billion years to form. These have been 150 years of sharply increasing climate impact. We must seek other paths and focus on renewable energy sources such as solar, wind, and biogas. From a security policy perspective, we are forced to consider supply security, which is why we cannot yet phase out fossil fuels.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text:
Once again, the summer has brought heat records and floods caused by climate change. Words must be followed by action if we are to succeed in slowing down the development, and we cannot avoid also looking at what we eat, how we heat our homes, how much we drive gasoline-powered cars, and how much we fly.  
Many people are in the process of changing their habits, but it is happening too slowly. The wishful thinking is that everyone will gradually become more aware of their responsibility, but we do not have time.  
Therefore, we must take the next step and regulate our behavior with taxes. Is it fun? No. Is it necessary? Yes.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: The UK must ensure energy independence through renewable energy. By using renewable energy, we ensure that the UK is as independent as possible from foreign states. At the same time, we ensure that the climate does not deteriorate. If the climate deteriorates, conflicts increase, and we get a much more insecure world. By investing in renewable energy, we ensure the UK’s energy independence while not worsening the climate crisis.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: Development aid is important for recipient countries to be able to build a democratic society with economic growth, which will provide its citizens with better and healthier life opportunities, and which can serve as a counterbalance to undemocratic governments. It can also help protect the planet from the overexploitation of natural resources by giving citizens better conditions for education and thus a wider range of job opportunities.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: We need to promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea, as it is a resource that exists underground and does not need to be manufactured. In contrast to solar and wind energy, large investments must be made in turbines and solar panels. Large amounts of land must be used, which could have contributed to food production. As a result, we could end up in a situation where we are no longer self-sufficient and have to import from other countries, which most likely also cannot supply themselves. We will be left with "black" fields that once changed appearance and color with the seasons.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: It is important that the CO2 tax is also applied to imported goods, so that transport is also taken into account. This is better than having the producer pay; this avoids distortion of competition and puts British goods in a better competitive position.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: Development aid is important for several reasons. Ethically, because we have a responsibility towards people affected by, for example, hunger, drought, and climate change. For the climate and nature, to be able to support the green transition and prevent the destruction of nature and our shared planet. Economically and for global security, as countries and populations in positive development are better trading partners and help prevent new wars and conflicts.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: Our entire way of cooperating with other countries – not least the developing countries – is undergoing major restructuring. This is because the future is no longer determined by money alone, but by access to raw materials, labor, and knowledge. In many developing countries, there are resources that provide the greatest added value for the industrialized countries. We can only promote development in these countries through aid that ensures they become self-sufficient in political leadership, business management, and education. Africa is a good example, where we can expect a quadrupling of middle incomes over the next 20-30 years. This creates peace.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text:
I think the government should reduce foreign aid, as I feel that much of the money disappears into thin air.  
My knowledge is not very extensive, but I wonder why many countries have not progressed further in their political development. I worry about whether the aid reaches those who need it. My knowledge is only from social media. I support helping, but I lack insight and knowledge.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: Taxes are not the solution. The solution is innovation. By investing in future solutions that ensure that everyday goods which emit CO2, such as animal production, emit less in the future, we maintain production in the UK and can even gain an advantage by being a country that has solved the problem. By making a product more expensive through taxes, we move the market away from the UK and abroad. This can potentially lead to greater emissions, as the goods then also have to be transported. The UK has always understood how to develop, not least within the agricultural sector. We can do this with knowledge and without taxes.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: Development aid saves lives, creates stability, and prevents crises. It promotes education, equality, and combats climate change. It is both ethically right and in the UK’s own interest. The aid works – therefore we should not cut it, but maintain it. At the same time, a reduction in aid could lead to many more immigrants to the EU and the UK.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: Energy independence is important, but the greatest possible independence from climate impacts is also important. Extraction of gas and oil can, for a short period, contribute to British energy independence, but will also contribute to increased challenges in adapting to climate change. We can produce all the energy we need using renewable sources, especially solar and wind. This energy supply simultaneously reduces climate impacts, is a decentralized production, and is therefore robust against all forms of attack; moreover, solar and wind are by far the cheapest forms of energy.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: We all have a responsibility for the climate, and we owe it to future generations to do something effective to reduce CO2 emissions. For me, it is not a question of whether we SHOULD do something, but rather a question of finding the most effective way to do it. We cannot continue our previous practices.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: CO2 and climate change are connected, and the extreme weather phenomena affect us all. That is why I think we all need to take some responsibility for fixing the climate, so that our children and grandchildren also have a future. In the UK, we will not save the world with our contributions in the form of taxes, but if we use taxes to promote new technology, our knowledge can both contribute to CO2 reduction and create new British jobs.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: Try to imagine if it were you or your family who had to flee from war or persecution. Wouldn't you hope that someone would take you in? The UK has both the resources and the space to help more people, and experience shows that many quickly contribute with work, culture, and new perspectives. It's not just about helping – it's about standing firm on our values of humanity and solidarity.
Issue: accept more asylum seekers fleeing war or persecution.

Text: We are all immigrants. It is only a question of when we arrived. We should be open to helping others in need. As long as we have the opportunity and space to help, we should do so: until our country is flooded due to the climate crisis and rising sea levels. Then I hope that other countries will take us in.
Issue: accept more asylum seekers fleeing war or persecution.

Text: When we introduce a CO2 tax on goods and energy that pollute the environment, etc., it will become more attractive to buy, for example, foods that are healthier both for people and for the environment, and to use the most sustainable energy. The choice that is best for the environment, climate, and health should be the cheapest. This will also encourage producers to think more sustainably.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: Taxes are not a viable solution; it’s a never-ending spiral. Money is not a problem in our part of the world—it’s the lack of personal sense and responsibility for anything beyond one’s own life. The retail sector should also take greater responsibility and stop marketing beef, wine, and spirits as the predominant part of the food pyramid. But they hide behind the claim that it’s what the consumer wants, because the consumer doesn’t see many alternatives, and that is the responsibility of the retail sector.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: We are facing enormous environmental and climate challenges both in the UK and in the rest of the world. If we want our children and grandchildren to inherit a planet that can still provide the basis for a dignified life for everyone, then we must act now. We need to regulate and reduce our consumption—and especially our use of energy—if we are to succeed.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: We must help people who are fleeing from war, but the authorities need to get better at ensuring that it is the right people who are granted residence permits. The asylum authorities must not contact applicants’ home countries, and there are people who come with false stories and fabricated identities. This is a well-known problem, and we should look at the current conventions in this area.
Issue: accept more asylum seekers fleeing war or persecution.

Text: I agree that the government should promote the securing of energy independence, but it must be done in a way that does not put additional strain on the environment. I believe it is important to support the development of more CO2-neutral energy sources. For example, this could be hydrogen, but it is important that environmental considerations are taken into account throughout the entire process. That means there must be transparency in the entire supply chain.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: We need to take these measures partly to reduce CO2 emissions and promote renewable energy production. In the same context, VAT should be removed from the portion of food/vegetables that is produced exclusively organically or biodynamically/regeneratively. In this way, I am convinced that consumption will change in the future, and many fellow citizens will experience a higher quality of life, which should also be an important element in gaining support from the population.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: Helping those in need in their local area is an important task for a country as privileged as the UK. For many years, we have not had war, and the threat of natural disasters is very low here. Therefore, we must help the people who are hit harder where they live, but with development and "help to self-help" in mind.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: I do not think the government should reduce spending on development aid, because we have a moral obligation to help people in need—and because, in this way, we can reduce the number of citizens from poor countries in the South who seek to move north for a tolerable life. We should use development aid to create lasting solutions regarding jobs, supplies, and educational opportunities in the countries that need it. If we reduce it, we will end up only offering emergency aid and thus have to spend many more resources keeping migrants out at the borders.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: If we place a tax on what pollutes/emits the most, we simultaneously get the most fair and effective way to reduce emissions. For example, beef might become more expensive, as this type of meat has high emissions. On the other hand, chicken and lentils, which have relatively low emissions, would become cheaper. It could be even better if the revenue is used to lower taxes and VAT on the products that emit the least.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: Many groceries are produced with a high CO2 footprint. This has consequences for the environment and global warming. For example, meat and dairy products have a very high CO2 footprint. Meat is a climate-impacting food that is produced from animals which emit greenhouse gases/methane. The animals are fed with feed that requires the clearing/burning of rainforests to make room for fields, such as soybean cultivation. Fossil energy sources emit enormous amounts of CO2. We should therefore focus on more renewable energy sources such as solar and wind energy.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: Lack of water. Lack of food. Lack of security. Lack of hope for the future.  This is the reality for far too large a part of the world’s population. People who have no hope for the future—for themselves, for their children, for future generations—will, if it is at all possible, flee to parts of the world where there is water, food, security, and hope for their children. The UK must give these people a future where they live. Together with other wealthy countries, we must take responsibility for developing agriculture, schools, infrastructure, and, not least, democracy. There must be hope for the future everywhere in the world!
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: We live in a time with major challenges regarding climate and sustainability. Here it is important that everyone contributes to reducing CO2 emissions. One of the tools is that we as consumers must be helped to buy products that are more CO2-friendly, and to increase taxes on food and other items that are the most harmful.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: It doesn’t work to have an economy where you can pollute our shared climate without having to pay the bill. That means far too many people don’t switch to greener production, but just keep on polluting. The green choice should be the cheapest. Here in the UK, we have an opportunity to lead the way and be the example that other countries can follow to create an economy where the polluter pays, and where it is therefore also economically beneficial to be greener and take care of our shared planet. That requires CO2 taxes on the goods and production that pollute the most.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: If we are to restore balance to the Earth's ecosystems and ensure that our children and future generations have access to clean air and drinking water, and if we are to prevent climate disasters that we ourselves have created in the future, it is essential to reduce CO2 emissions and pollution where it is most effective, and here groceries and energy play a very significant role, because it is very large amounts of CO2 and pollution that we can prevent here, and because we can all actively contribute. At the same time, the "sacrifice" we must make together is modest. It is simply one of the best ways to achieve our goals.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: A lot of research has been done on the effects of development aid. The overall conclusion is that development aid does not develop countries. Countries are developed by political reforms, which only the countries themselves can implement, and development aid, in the worst case, delays the implementation of these reforms. In many other cases, development aid makes no difference at all.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: When politicians wants to ban the import of Russian gas from 2027, we naturally shouldn’t fetch and transport extra oil and gas from the Middle East and the USA. That money should be spent in Europe, where we can. We must not compromise our climate goals, but we also shouldn’t spend our money on transport that increases the climate burden – nor should we spend money on oil in a country that threatens us with tariffs and with annexing Greenland.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: We share the goal of becoming independent of fossil fuels. The UK is far ahead in this area, and our technologies are making the world greener. But there is still a long way to go. Until then, millions of people depend on fossil fuels to stay warm in winter and get to work. Therefore, the question is: Should we buy it from people who are fighting us—physically and mentally—or should we be independent of our enemies by utilizing our own resources? Therefore, this is not about reducing green ambitions, but about ensuring national security and everyday life during the transition period for millions.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: The most important thing in politics is to help make the UK better for the next generation – and one of the most important tasks here is to address climate and environmental challenges. That’s why we must make an active effort to reduce CO2 emissions. I am aware that many people think it doesn’t make a difference, but if everyone thinks that way, nothing will happen. So we all need to contribute what we can – and for the individual, it is a very small cost.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: We need to reduce our CO2 footprint. This should not be left to the individual citizen, as it can be both difficult to figure out and practically impossible, because so much of it is embedded in the structures. By letting the prices of groceries reflect their actual emissions, the food that is best for the climate will become the cheapest—and conversely, the food that harms the planet will become the most expensive. This will create an economic incentive to choose the most climate-friendly options. It would be very good to combine this with a green check for those with the lowest incomes, so that there is not too much economic inequality.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: There is a huge inequality between countries in the world; among other things, there are major challenges in the Global South and in South America. It is of great interest to an economy like the UK’s and to the EU that there is strong development in developing countries. For example, in relation to our security and migration. So I do not think we should reduce spending on development aid—although I do think we should develop the aid to ensure that it creates development in the country being supported, and that we reduce the return commission.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: In an uncertain time with war in Europe and the Middle East, we must and should secure the British defense. Therefore, it does not make sense for us to give so much money to development aid—especially not to countries that do not fight for freedom and democracy. That is why we should reduce spending on development aid and use it to strengthen the British defense. British tax money should first and foremost be used to secure the British people and the UK.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: It is important to place a CO2 tax at the production stage, as it is the most cost-effective way to reduce emissions from various sectors. If a CO2 tax is introduced, companies will reduce their emissions in order to gain a competitive advantage over those companies that do not adapt.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: We need to introduce a CO2 tax on the most environmentally and climate-damaging goods and energy in order to regulate behavior. The climate challenges are now so great that it is urgent to reduce CO2 emissions. If we do nothing, the world will become warmer with catastrophic consequences: more extreme weather, drought, and hunger in poorer countries south of Europe, leading to war and migration. CO2 emissions will not only harm nature and our environment; they will also negatively affect our society. A tax will also shift consumption towards more climate-friendly goods, which are often also the healthiest.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: Already now we are feeling the consequences of the climate crisis in the form of, for example, more frequent floods. Other countries are experiencing the same extreme weather phenomena to an even greater extent. This has significant costs. That is why the UK, together with the countries of the world, agrees that we must reduce our CO2 emissions by phasing out oil and gas extraction and instead making a massive investment in renewable energy. We should instead invest in green energy. We owe that both to each other and to future generations. Furthermore, green energy is also cheaper than oil and gas and much better for the environment. It’s a win-win.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: If we are to succeed with the green transition, more sectors need to contribute: industry, agriculture, the transport sector, and others. With a tax, we can make it more expensive to pollute heavily and thereby make it more attractive for Brits to choose climate-friendly options. However, there must be social balance so that everyday life can still work for Brits with a low income. Green transition with social justice.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: A CO2 tax on British-produced everyday goods risks leading to production moving abroad without actually reducing CO2 emissions globally—perhaps even the opposite. Therefore, such a tax does not make sense. If such a tax is to be introduced, it should be applied to the product in the refrigerated display, so that all goods are affected regardless of where they are produced.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: We need to use the energy sources we have available while we are in a transition to new forms of energy. It costs a great deal of money to develop and implement the new energy sources that, overall, we would all like to use. It is about the average Dane, who must be able to afford and thus accept the transition. If it becomes a costly expense for the average Dane, there will be resistance, making it much more difficult for politicians to carry out the transition. We must also acknowledge that emissions from oil and gas today are far below the levels of just a few years ago.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: Development aid is not charity: it is an investment. If we invest massively in enabling developing countries to develop, it benefits both them and us. Only in this way can we counter the large flows of refugees caused by poor living conditions—for it is understandable that people want to leave a country where there is no future.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: We need to achieve the green transition, but we must do it wisely. Agriculture in particular is one of the major emitters of greenhouse gases. But if we put a tax on everyday goods from, for example, agriculture, then only British consumers will pay the tax. Agricultural exports will not be affected. If, on the other hand, we tax the actual production, the farmer will have an incentive to reduce their emissions, save money, and thus be able to lower the price of their products. Regarding energy, we need to be careful not to move too quickly. That could create resistance to the transition.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: The world’s resources—political and economic—are very unequally distributed. It is both politically and morally important and right that the UK contributes some of our wealth to change the structures that keep people trapped in poverty and inequality elsewhere in the world and to strengthen people’s ability to decide for themselves how their societies should develop. Besides being just, it is also in our own interest. Ensuring that people have good and secure lives in well-functioning and peaceful societies prevents conflict and war, and thus also prevents people from migrating or being forced to flee.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: There is no doubt whatsoever that we will need fossil fuels for many years to come. If we stop producing them ourselves, it will make us (even more) dependent on the many dictatorships that produce these fuels. It will strengthen them economically — and ultimately militarily. We become weaker — they become stronger. The example of Russia is frightening.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: It is important that we continue to provide a high level of development aid. It has a positive impact on development in developing countries, which is good because it gives those countries the opportunity to shape their own future. Furthermore, it is positive that we as a country take the lead and show the way for those who may not contribute as much.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: Development aid is, as a concept, a good idea. But unfortunately, the concept is not black and white when we look at how it is used today. Among other things, we still send aid to countries such as China. There are other countries that likewise receive subsidies, where it is quite clear that, due to their economic capacity, they ought to be able to manage without it. Furthermore, we can see that development aid goes to countries that, at the same time, would not accept their own citizens if they were deported from the UK. One should not be able to receive aid in a country that does not wish to take responsibility for its own citizens.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: We must be 100% independent of fossil fuels and focus on renewable energy; we must protect ourselves against climate change. Energy policy is also security policy; we must not be in anyone’s pocket. When we produce alternative energy, we also create a lot of green jobs and a technology we can sell to others.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text:
Europe’s energy independence can be secured with green energy.
In Northern Europe, there is great potential for renewable energy.
From a climate policy perspective, it is important to reduce oil and gas extraction. Complete energy independence is not realistic, but it is possible in Europe to make a greater energy policy effort to increase the EU’s share of renewable energy. The EU has goals to ensure independence as well as a greater share of green energy.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: Consumers have a responsibility for climate action, but the British Parliament has the greatest responsibility for designing laws and regulations that support responsible climate action. Here, both parties go hand in hand. You often hear citizens say: "What can I do?" This desire should not be underestimated. Many experience climate change as very concerning and therefore wish to be part of the solution themselves. This applies to the purchase of food, clothing, and energy.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.

Text: We can achieve energy independence by promoting our investments in green solutions such as offshore wind, solar energy, P2X, etc. For the sake of future generations and our climate, we must lead the way by prioritizing green initiatives over oil and gas extraction. For decades, the UK has been at the forefront of green solutions, especially wind turbines, which have created a major industry for which we are known worldwide. We must maintain this.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: It is far better for both the UK and the individual asylum seeker who is fleeing to be helped in the local area. And that the UK supports the countries located in the surrounding regions. After that, it is important to have a common approach in Europe to the distribution of asylum seekers, once they have been well taken care of in the local areas. Historically, the UK has taken a large share of asylum seekers, and that is something that should be taken into account, and therefore the UK should not take in more asylum seekers.
Issue: accept more asylum seekers fleeing war or persecution.

Text: The oil industry belongs to the past and contributes to climate change and environmental pollution. Promoting oil and gas extraction in the UK is a short-term solution. Instead, we should invest in renewable energy, which is a sustainable and long-term solution that will also benefit generations into the future. If we do not solve the climate crisis, it is our children and grandchildren who will pay the price.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text:
Today, the EU imports enormous amounts of gas from Russia, which helps finance their invasion of Ukraine.  
In order to make the EU independent of Russian gas, huge investments are being planned in EU ports so that we can import liquefied gas from the USA, which, in addition to being bad for the climate, creates a new dependency.  Therefore, we should consider whether we can extract more gas from the North Sea instead. That would be better for the climate, Europe's security, and our economy.
Issue: promote oil and gas extraction in the North Sea to ensure energy independence.

Text: There is still inequality in the world, but fortunately the extent of extreme poverty is decreasing. This is partly due to the development aid that we in the wealthy countries have provided to people who are not as fortunate as we are. I believe that everyone agrees it is important to lift people out of poverty. If development aid were given solely as voluntary contributions, there would not be as much provided. The aid should be targeted at the countries and projects where it has the greatest effect, and it is reasonable to set requirements for the recipient countries. Without development aid, the flows of refugees would increase.
Issue: reduce spending in development aid.

Text: Introducing a CO2 tax on groceries and energy that pollute the most can have a social downside. If it is to be introduced, there must be consideration for the possibility of compensation or other schemes alongside it, to offset any inequality that may arise. An example could be a citizen living in a rural area because it is cheap to live there. But the house may still be heated with oil or gas, and the car is a used diesel car. This person could be forced to find another place to live if we do not remember to look at the whole situation.
Issue: introduce a CO2 tax on the most polluting groceries and energy to reduce emissions.
